elements.content: Synthesis of new cyclotetrasiloxane scaffolds containing peripherally functionalized 3-pyridyl moieties, [MeSiO­(CHCH3Py)]4 (L1) and [MeSiO­(CH2CH2 3Py)]4 (L2), and their reactivity studies with certain d10 metal ions are reported. The ligand L1 is obtained by the Heck-coupling reaction of tetramethyl tetravinyl tetrasiloxane (D4 vi) and 3-bromopyridine in the presence of the Pd(0) catalysts. The as-synthesized ligand L1 shows the presence of three stereoisomers, cis–trans–cis (L1A), cis–cis–trans (L1B), and all-trans (L1C), which are quantitatively separated by column chromatography. Subsequent reduction of L1A, L1B, and L1C with triethylsilane in the presence of catalytic amounts of Pd/C leads to the formation of the ligands L2A, L2B, and L2C with retention of stereochemistry due to the precursor moieties. Treatment of ZnI2 with L1A gives a one-dimensional coordination framework [(L1A)4(ZnI2)2]∞, 1. These 1D-chains are further connected by π–π stacking interactions between the pyridyl groups of the adjacent chains leading to the formation of a three-dimensional network with the topology of a PtS net. The reaction of silver nitrate with ligand L1B gives a chain like one-dimensional cationic coordination polymer {[(L1B)4Ag2]·2NO3·H2O·CH3OH }∞, 2, consisting of two different kinds of 32-membered macrocycles. Treatment of the all-trans ligand L2C with copper­(I) iodide salt results in the formation of a cubane-type Cu4I4 cluster MOF [(L2C)4Cu4I4]∞, 3, in a two-dimensional 4-connected uninodal sql/Shubnikov tetragonal plane net topology represented by the Schläfli symbol {44.62}. This MOF displays a thermochromic luminescence behavior due to Cu4I4 clusters showing an orange emission at 298 K and a blue emission at 77 K.

elements.content: Syntheses of three stereoisomers of new cyclotetrasiloxane scaffolds containing 3-pyridyl moieties, [MeSiO­(CHCH3Py)]4 (L1) and [MeSiO­(CH2CH2 3Py)]4 (L2), are reported. From the structures of three interesting coordination polymers, the stereochemistry of these ligands is established.

From the structures of three interesting coordination polymers, the stereochemistry of these ligands is established.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of new materials based on peripherally functionalized siloxanes have received considerable attention in materials science. This is primarily due to the similarities of the cyclic and cage siloxanes as small-molecule mimics for the silica-containing surfaces which exhibit diverse properties and functional behavior. One of the hallmark properties of the silica surfaces is the ability to host various metal ions on their surface for applications in heterogeneous catalysis and materials development. Thus, it would be interesting to mimic the structural and functional behavior of metalated silica surfaces by preparing metal complexes of peripherally functionalized cyclic and cage siloxanes. Also, metal complexes of such higher siloxanes would give enormous molecular level and structural insights for metal-containing surfaces and hybrid motifs containing metal–organic materials and silica surfaces. However, owing to the difficulties associated with obtaining crystalline solids, use of these scaffolds as ligand platforms/templates in building metal-containing assemblies has been limited to a very small number of systems such as the ones synthesized from silicon bound hydroxyl functionalities, a Ni(0) complex supported by the Si-bound vinyl groups, [(Ni­(P­{C6H4Me4)3}2­{μ-CH2CH­(Me)­Si­(μ-O)}4], and a Pt­(II) complex of a monoterpyridyl functionalized polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS). Apart from these, metal complexes of peripherally functionalized siloxane based ligands have been mostly restricted only to a simple disiloxane backbone. For instance, some interesting metal complexes of pyridyl group tethered disiloxanes and metalladisiloxanes with π-systems and azo functionalities as additional donors are known in the literature. In addition, cyclosiloxanes exist as a mixture of two or more stereoisomers complicating the quantitative purification and isolation of the obtained metal complexes. For example, the tetrahydroxy cyclotetrasiloxane [iPr­(OH)­SiO]4 is a stochastic mixture of four different isomers in all–cis, all-trans, cis–trans–cis, and cis–cis–trans geometries. In spite of these issues, we set out to employ a peripherally functionalized cyclotetrasiloxane motif as anchor for obtaining multinuclear metal complexes and frameworks since it emulates as a medium-sized building block for polymeric siloxanes and can provide better control during metalation reactions in comparison with the fully functionalized octameric POSS.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of new materials based on peripherally functionalized siloxanes have received considerable attention in materials science. This is primarily due to the similarities of the cyclic and cage siloxanes as small-molecule mimics for the silica-containing surfaces which exhibit diverse properties and functional behavior. One of the hallmark properties of the silica surfaces is the ability to host various metal ions on their surface for applications in heterogeneous catalysis and materials development. Thus, it would be interesting to mimic the structural and functional behavior of metalated silica surfaces by preparing metal complexes of peripherally functionalized cyclic and cage siloxanes. Also, metal complexes of such higher siloxanes would give enormous molecular level and structural insights for metal-containing surfaces and hybrid motifs containing metal-organic materials and silica surfaces. However, owing to the difficulties associated with obtaining crystalline solids, use of these scaffolds as ligand platforms/templates in building metal-containing assemblies has been limited to a very small number of systems such as the ones synthesized from silicon bound hydroxyl functionalities, a Ni(0) complex supported by the Si-bound vinyl groups, [(Ni(P{C6H4Me4)3}2{μ-CH2CH(Me)Si(μ-O)}4], and a Pt(II) complex of a monoterpyridyl functionalized polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS). Apart from these, metal complexes of peripherally functionalized siloxane based ligands have been mostly restricted only to a simple disiloxane backbone. For instance, some interesting metal complexes of pyridyl group tethered disiloxanes and metalladisiloxanes with π-systems and azo functionalities as additional donors are known in the literature. In addition, cyclosiloxanes exist as a mixture of two or more stereoisomers complicating the quantitative purification and isolation of the obtained metal complexes. For example, the tetrahydroxy cyclotetrasiloxane [iPr(OH)SiO]4 is a stochastic mixture of four different isomers in all-cis, all-trans, cis-trans-cis, and cis-cis-trans geometries. In spite of these issues, we set out to employ a peripherally functionalized cyclotetrasiloxane motif as anchor for obtaining multinuclear metal complexes and frameworks since it emulates as a medium-sized building block for polymeric siloxanes and can provide better control during metalation reactions in comparison with the fully functionalized octameric POSS.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis and separation of the stereoisomers of 3-pyridyl functionalized cyclotetrasiloxane ligands, [MeSiO­(CHCH3Py)]4 (L1) and [MeSiO­(CH2CH2 3Py)]4 (L2). Three isomers have been isolated for each of these ligands in cis–trans–cis (L1A and L2A), cis–cis–trans (L1B and L2B), and all-trans (L1C and L2C) geometries (). The existence of these isomers has been probed by 1H, 13C, and 29Si NMR spectroscopy. Further, their stereochemistry has been unambiguously confirmed by the single crystal X-ray analysis of some of their corresponding complexes 1, [(L1A)4(ZnI2)2]∞, 2, {[(L1B)4Ag2]·2NO3·H2O·CH3OH}∞, and 3, [(L2C)4Cu4I4]∞. Separation of stereoisomers of cyclosiloxanes is a challenging task, and the reported metal complexes based on these ligands is the first instance, to the best of our knowledge, where topologically unique coordination polymers have been isolated from stereochemically distinct cyclosiloxane scaffolds.

Three isomers have been isolated for each of these ligands in cis-trans-cis (L1A and L2A), cis-cis-trans (L1B and L2B), and all-trans (L1C and L2C) geometries (). The existence of these isomers has been probed by 1H, 13C, and 29Si NMR spectroscopy. Further, their stereochemistry has been unambiguously confirmed by the single crystal X-ray analysis of some of their corresponding complexes 1, [(L1A)4(ZnI2)2]∞, 2, {[(L1B)4Ag2]⋅2NO3⋅H2O⋅CH3OH}∞, and 3, [(L2C)4Cu4I4]∞. elements.content: All manipulations were performed under a dry atmosphere in standard Schlenk glassware. 2,4,6,8-Tetramethyl-2,4,6,8-tetravinyl-cyclotetrasiloxane (D4 Vi), 3-bromopyridine, Pd­[P­(t-Bu)3]2, CuI, ZnI2, and AgNO3 were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. NMR spectra were recorded on a 400 MHz Bruker FT spectrometer (1H NMR, 400 MHz; 13C­{1H} NMR, 100 MHz; 29Si NMR, 80 MHz) at room temperature using SiMe4 as external standards. FT-IR spectra were taken on a PerkinElmer spectrophotometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained from a PerkinElmer STA-6000 thermogravimetric analyzer. The differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) data were recorded on a TA Instruments Q20 model instrument. The absorption and emission studies were done by a PerkinElmer Lambda 45 UV–vis spectrophotometer and SPEX Fluorolog HORIBA JOBIN VYON fluorescence spectrophotometer with a double-grating 0.22 m SPEX 1680 monochromator and a 450W Xe lamp as the excitation source. The excitation and emission spectra of the complexes were corrected at the instrumental function.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

All manipulations were performed under a dry atmosphere in standard Schlenk glassware. 2,4,6,8-Tetramethyl-2,4,6,8-tetravinyl-cyclotetrasiloxane (D4 Vi), 3-bromopyridine, Pd[P(t-Bu)3]2, CuI, ZnI2, and AgNO3 were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. NMR spectra were recorded on a 400 MHz Bruker FT spectrometer (1H NMR, 400 MHz; 13C{1H} NMR, 100 MHz; 29Si NMR, 80 MHz) at room temperature using SiMe4 as external standards. FT-IR spectra were taken on a PerkinElmer spectrophotometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained from a PerkinElmer STA-6000 thermogravimetric analyzer. The differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) data were recorded on a TA Instruments Q20 model instrument. The absorption and emission studies were done by a PerkinElmer Lambda 45 UV-vis spectrophotometer and SPEX Fluorolog HORIBA JOBIN VYON fluorescence spectrophotometer with a double-grating 0.22 m SPEX 1680 monochromator and a 450W Xe lamp as the excitation source. The excitation and emission spectra of the complexes were corrected at the instrumental function.

elements.content: L1: 3-Bromopyridine (7.18 g 44 mmol) and D4 Vi (3.92 g, 11 mmol) were kept under nitrogen in a 250 mL two neck round-bottom flask, equipped with magnetic stirrer and reflux condenser. The flask was purged with nitrogen for 15 min at room temperature, and then 15 mL of triethylamine and Pd­[P­(tBu3)2] (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was then stirred at 90 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, hexane (50 mL) was added, and the mixture was washed with water in a separating funnel. The organic layer was separated, filtered through Celite, and evaporated in vacuum, to yield 60% of the crude L1 as a yellowish-brown oily compound. The crude mixture was purified by column chromatography using tetrahydrofuran and chloroform (20:80) as eluent which gave three stereoisomers of L1, namely, the cis–trans–cis L1A, cis–cis–trans L1B, and all-trans L1C, in the respective 35, 60, and 5% compositions.

Syntheses

L1: 3-Bromopyridine (7.18 g 44 mmol) and D4 Vi (3.92 g, 11 mmol) were kept under nitrogen in a 250 mL two neck round-bottom flask, equipped with magnetic stirrer and reflux condenser. The flask was purged with nitrogen for 15 min at room temperature, and then 15 mL of triethylamine and Pd[P(tBu3)2] (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was then stirred at 90 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, hexane (50 mL) was added, and the mixture was washed with water in a separating funnel. The organic layer was separated, filtered through Celite, and evaporated in vacuum, to yield 60% of the crude L1 as a yellowish-brown oily compound. The crude mixture was purified by column chromatography using tetrahydrofuran and chloroform (20:80) as eluent which gave three stereoisomers of L1, namely, the cis-trans-cis L1A, cis-cis-trans L1B, and all-trans L1C, in the respective 35, 60, and 5% compositions.

L2: To a stirred mixture of the ligand L1 (L1A or L1B or L1C) (0.25 g, 0.38 mmol) and 10% palladium on carbon (2.5 mg) in MeOH (5–10 mL) taken in a two-necked round-bottom flask at room temperature under inert atmosphere was added triethylsilane (1.8 g, 15 mmol) dropwise from a pressure-equalizing funnel. When the reaction was complete (TLC), the mixture was filtered through Celite, and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The product was purified by using a short silica gel column to yield the respective products of L2.

elements.content: Reflections were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex Duo diffractometer at 100 K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) for 2 and 3. For 1, the data was collected on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer fitted with a microfocus detector at 100 K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Structures were refined by full matrix least-squares against F 2 using all data (SHELX). Crystallographic data for all these compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2, Supporting Information. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically if not stated otherwise. Hydrogen atoms were constrained in geometric positions to their parent atoms. Crystals of 1 and 2 were weakly diffracting at higher angles, and hence a 2θ = 50° cutoff was applied. Owing to the weak diffraction data and partially opaque nature of the crystals, the C and N atoms of the pyridyl vinyl groups in 2 were refined isotropically. Only one of the two nitrate groups in 2 was located; the other nitrate group was disordered with solvate groups and hence has been removed by the squeeze routine of the Platon program. The TGA of 2 showed a 5% weight loss up to 110 °C corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of methanol (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The tetrasiloxane ring and one of the vinyl carbons in all four vinyl pyridyl moieties in 1 were disordered over two positions and hence were freely refined using the SAME/SADI restraints. The Zn bound iodine atoms in 1 were disordered over three positions and refined by the SUMP command. Crystals of 3 were very poor in quality, and we could just manage to solve the structure of the compound. The data were very weak and of poor quality as indicated by high R(int) and R(σ) values. We have refined the structure with truncated data (1A) because of the low resolution of the reflection pattern. We have also tried several lower symmetry space groups; none of them gave a considerable improvement. For example, in the Pc space group the siloxane ring shifts away slightly of what would be the 2-fold axis of P2/c. There were also difference peaks in regions where one would not expect them. This may be due to nonmerohedral twinning. However, on the whole, we believe the disorder of the ligand in 3 is intrinsic in nature owing to the flexibility of the siloxane ring and the ethyl pyridyl side chains favoring more than one conformation for the ligand without affecting the coordination geometry. This becomes apparent when one looks at the thermal parameters, which become larger the farther the atoms are to the center of the ligand and reach a maximum at the siloxane ring. Because there was a large number of domains, it was impossible to refine a meaningful model of the disorder. Nevertheless, all connectivity patterns of the molecule were unambiguously established in the crystal structure of 3. However, owing to its high R-factor (about 15%), the bond lengths and bond angles in it have to be treated with caution. In addition, all the C and N atoms in 3 were refined isotropically due to poor diffraction data.

Crystallography

All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically if not stated otherwise. Hydrogen atoms were constrained in geometric positions to their parent atoms. Crystals of 1 and 2 were weakly diffracting at higher angles, and hence a 2θ = 50° cutoff was applied. Owing to the weak diffraction data and partially opaque nature of the crystals, the C and N atoms of the pyridyl vinyl groups in 2 were refined isotropically. Only one of the two nitrate groups in 2 was located; the other nitrate group was disordered with solvate groups and hence has been removed by the squeeze routine of the Platon program. The TGA of 2 showed a 5% weight loss up to 110 °C corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of methanol (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The tetrasiloxane ring and one of the vinyl carbons in all four vinyl pyridyl moieties in 1 were disordered over two positions and hence were freely refined using the SAME/SADI restraints. The Zn bound iodine atoms in 1 were disordered over three positions and refined by the SUMP command. Crystals of 3 were very poor in quality, and we could just manage to solve the structure of the compound. The data were very weak and of poor quality as indicated by high R(int) and R(σ) values. We have refined the structure with truncated data (1A) because of the low resolution of the reflection pattern. We have also tried several lower symmetry space groups; none of them gave a considerable improvement. For example, in the Pc space group the siloxane ring shifts away slightly of what would be the 2-fold axis of P2/c. There were also difference peaks in regions where one would not expect them. This may be due to nonmerohedral twinning. However, on the whole, we believe the disorder of the ligand in 3 is intrinsic in nature owing to the flexibility of the siloxane ring and the ethyl pyridyl side chains favoring more than one conformation for the ligand without affecting the coordination geometry. This becomes apparent when one looks at the thermal parameters, which become larger the farther the atoms are to the center of the ligand and reach a maximum at the siloxane ring. Because there was a large number of domains, it was impossible to refine a meaningful model of the disorder. Nevertheless, all connectivity patterns of the molecule were unambiguously established in the crystal structure of 3. However, owing to its high R-factor (about 15%), the bond lengths and bond angles in it have to be treated with caution. In addition, all the C and N atoms in 3 were refined isotropically due to poor diffraction data.

elements.content: The luminescent lifetime of 3 was measured at room temperature (298 K) as well as low temperature (77 K). The room-temperature phosphorescence decay profiles were fitted to bi- or triexponential curves. The 77 K phosphorescence decay profiles were fitted to monoexponential equations. In all the cases, the lifetimes were fitted by using the DAS software. Throughout this paper, the lifetimes of bi- or triexponential curves are discussed only with respect to the highest lifetimes for the sake of simplicity.
elements.clean_text:
Lifetime Measurements

The luminescent lifetime of 3 was measured at room temperature (298 K) as well as low temperature (77 K). The room-temperature phosphorescence decay profiles were fitted to bi- or triexponential curves. The 77 K phosphorescence decay profiles were fitted to monoexponential equations. In all the cases, the lifetimes were fitted by using the DAS software. Throughout this paper, the lifetimes of bi- or triexponential curves are discussed only with respect to the highest lifetimes for the sake of simplicity.

elements.content: The density functional theory (DFT) calculations for the stereoisomers of L1 and L2 were performed using the Gaussian 09 program package. The B3LYP exchange-correlation functional was used throughout for all calculations along with 6-31g­(d,p) basis sets. The stereogeometry of the ligand isomers was prefixed, and their energies were optimized during the calculations.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

The density functional theory (DFT) calculations for the stereoisomers of L1 and L2 were performed using the Gaussian 09 program package. The B3LYP exchange-correlation functional was used throughout for all calculations along with 6-31g(d,p) basis sets. The stereogeometry of the ligand isomers was prefixed, and their energies were optimized during the calculations.

elements.content: The ligand L1 was synthesized from the reaction of precursor tetramer D4 vi with 3-bromopyridine in the presence of Pd­[P­(tBu3)2] catalyst and triethylamine as base. The progress of the reaction was monitored by 1H NMR with the change in chemical shift of the Si-bound vinyl protons from 5.80 to 6.10 ppm for D4 vi to around 6.45 and 7.29 ppm for L1. The crude product was purified by column chromatography using tetrahydrofuran and dichloromethane (20:80) as eluent which gave three stereoisomers of L1, namely the cis–trans–cis L1A, cis–cis–trans L1B and all-trans L1C, in the respective 35%, 60%, and 5% compositions. Although there are several methods available for obtaining peripherally modified cyclotetrasiloxanes, the Heck-coupling reaction was found to be successful in this case exhibiting an excellent functional group tolerance and good stereochemical separation. It is worth noting that a single cyclic tetrasiloxane containing propylammonium trifluoromethanesulfonate and methyl side groups in cis–trans–cis geometry has been recently synthesized from the hydrolytic condensation of 3-aminopropyldiethoxymethylsilane.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Spectra

The ligand L1 was synthesized from the reaction of precursor tetramer D4 vi with 3-bromopyridine in the presence of Pd[P(tBu3)2] catalyst and triethylamine as base. The progress of the reaction was monitored by 1H NMR with the change in chemical shift of the Si-bound vinyl protons from 5.80 to 6.10 ppm for D4 vi to around 6.45 and 7.29 ppm for L1. The crude product was purified by column chromatography using tetrahydrofuran and dichloromethane (20:80) as eluent which gave three stereoisomers of L1, namely the cis-trans-cis L1A, cis-cis-trans L1B and all-trans L1C, in the respective 35%, 60%, and 5% compositions. Although there are several methods available for obtaining peripherally modified cyclotetrasiloxanes, the Heck-coupling reaction was found to be successful in this case exhibiting an excellent functional group tolerance and good stereochemical separation. It is worth noting that a single cyclic tetrasiloxane containing propylammonium trifluoromethanesulfonate and methyl side groups in cis-trans-cis geometry has been recently synthesized from the hydrolytic condensation of 3-aminopropyldiethoxymethylsilane.

elements.clean_text: 1  Reaction Schemes and Conditions for Synthesis of L1 and L2

elements.content: The 29Si NMR spectrum of L1A gave a single peak at −31.2 ppm indicating that all four Si atoms are equivalent in the cis–trans–cis geometry. Similarly, the Si-bound methyl groups gave a single resonance in the 1H and 13C NMR spectrum at 0.37 and −0.26 ppm, respectively. The signals due to all four vinyl moieties and pyridyl groups in L1A were also found to be equivalent. The vinyl groups gave two doublets at 6.46 and 7.09 ppm; the pyridyl groups gave four signals centered at 7.24, 7.73, 8.50, and 8.63 ppm. In contrast, the cis–cis–trans isomer L1B showed three unique environments for four Si atoms in it. In L1B, The methyl groups present on Si1, Si2, and Si3 are located at the equatorial positions whereas that of Si4 is located at the axial position. As a result, Si1, Si3, and Si4 possess chemically different environments, and Si2 has an environment equivalent to that of Si1 (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Thus, the major peak at −31.1 ppm in the 29Si NMR spectrum of L1B corresponds to the Si1 and Si2 atoms with its two neighboring Si-Me groups located in the mixed axial–equatorial environment. The lower intensity peak at −31.0 ppm corresponds to Si3, which contains an equatorial methyl group (as that of Si1), with both of its neighboring Si-Me groups at equatorial positions. The fourth silicon atom, Si4, having an axially located methyl group and two neighboring equatorially directed Si-Me groups is in a totally different environment and gave rise to a signal somewhat shifted at −31.3 ppm. Similarly, it showed three peaks at 0.37, 0.38, and 0.40 ppm (in 1:1:2 ratio) in 1H NMR and two peaks at −0.31 and −0.16 ppm in 13C NMR for the Si-Me groups. The vinyl protons in L1B gave a set of two doublets in the 1:3 ratios at 6.46 and 7.09 ppm. Similarly, the pyridyl groups, owing to their two unique conformations, displayed two sets of four chemical shift values in 3:1 ratio in the range between 7.21 and 8.72 ppm. The ligand L1C showed similar 29Si and 1H NMR spectra as compared to that of L1A with marginal changes in the chemical shift values. The 29Si NMR spectrum of L1C gave a single peak at −31.1 ppm, and the silicon bound methyl groups were observed as a single resonance at 0.42 ppm in the 1H NMR spectrum (, and Figures S2–S10, Supporting Information). However, these isomers were distinguished from their R f values (0.56, 0.34, and 0.12 for L1A, L1B, and L1C, respectively, after two runs in the DCM:THF (80:20) mixture) on TLC strips.

elements.content: In order to obtain more flexible ligands based on the tetrasiloxane platform, all three isomers of L1 (L1A, L1B, and L1C) were individually subjected to the reduction reaction of the vinylic bonds utilizing triethylsilane as reducing agent. As observed before, the 29Si NMR spectra of both L2A and L2C exhibit single resonances (at −20.4 ppm) owing to similar environments for all four Si atoms, whereas three different signals were observed in the ratio of 1:2:1 for L2B (at −20.7, −20.5, and −20.4 ppm), signifying the retention of its cis–cis–trans geometry. Similarly, the 1H NMR spectra of L2A and L2C showed single resonances for the methyl protons at 0.14 and 0.15 ppm, respectively, while L2B exhibits two overlapping peaks at 0.12 ppm. The 13C NMR spectrum of L2B gave three peaks at −0.57, −0.54, and −0.47 ppm for methyl carbons, whereas L2A showed a single peak at −0.52 ppm. The protons due to the orthogonally attached ethyl pyridyl groups in all three isomers exhibit similar peak patterns due to the flexible nature of these side arms (, and Figures S10–S19, Supporting Information).

The protons due to the orthogonally attached ethyl pyridyl groups in all three isomers exhibit similar peak patterns due to the flexible nature of these side arms (, and Figures S10-S19, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Furthermore, all of these ligands were subjected to thermogravimetric (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) analysis to understand their thermal behavior (Figures S20–S27, Supporting Information). The TGA profiles indicate that the decomposition temperature of these ligands varies between 120 and 190 °C. In both L1 and L2 series, the all-trans isomer (L1C and L2C) exhibits lower stabilities, with the respective decomposition values of 120 and 150 °C, in comparison with the other two isomers. Also, from the DSC profiles, it can be observed that the stereochemical isomers of both L1 and L2 exhibit distinct crystallization and/or melting temperatures below 0 °C (Table S3, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Further, the metalation reactions of all these ligands were tested with several metal salts, especially those of certain d10 metal ions. The reaction of ZnI2 with L1A in 2:1 ratio at room temperature in methanol medium gave a white solid. Layering a methanolic solution of ZnI2 onto a THF solution of L1A gave single crystals of 1. The SCXRD analysis of 1 showed the formation of the one-dimensional coordination polymeric structure of composition [(L1A)4(ZnI2)2]∞. The reaction of L1B (in DCM) and AgNO3 (in water) in the layering method yielded the cationic one-dimensional coordination polymer 2 of formula {[(L1B)4Ag2]·2NO3·H2O·CH3OH}∞. An interesting two-dimensional cubane-type Cu4I4 cluster MOF 3 of formula [(L2C)4Cu4I4]∞ was crystallized from layering the MeCN solution of CuI to a DCM solution of L2C. However, treatment of CuI with any of the ligands of the L2 family in MeCN/DCM medium gave rise to almost identical solids 3a. Due to the amorphous nature of the bulk samples of 3a, the PXRD profiles of 3 and 3a could not be matched. Individual investigation of the photophysical properties of all these solids showed almost identical thermochromic behavior typical of cubane-type Cu4I4 clusters and emission characteristics (vide supra). Also, both 3 and 3a gave comparable TGA profiles indicating close structural similarities between them (Figure S28, Supporting Information). This may be attributed to the flexibility of the ligand L2, which includes the conformation of the siloxane ring and the configuration of its side chains. Due to the multitude of degrees of freedom, there may be more than one configuration of the ligand L2 that can support the same coordination geometry with respect to the Cu4I4 cluster.

elements.content: All the obtained tetrasiloxane ligands (L1A, L1B, L1C, L2A, L2B, and L2C) are colorless oily liquids. DFT (B3LYP-6-31g­(d,p)) level energy optimizations show that all the stereoisomers of L1 possess similar energetics (Figure S29, Supporting Information). However, the stereoconformations of these ligands can be gleaned from the crystal structure analysis of the metal complexes 1, 2, and 3 that are derived from some of these ligands ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

All the obtained tetrasiloxane ligands (L1A, L1B, L1C, L2A, L2B, and L2C) are colorless oily liquids. DFT (B3LYP-6-31g(d,p)) level energy optimizations show that all the stereoisomers of L1 possess similar energetics (Figure S29, Supporting Information). However, the stereoconformations of these ligands can be gleaned from the crystal structure analysis of the metal complexes 1, 2, and 3 that are derived from some of these ligands ().

elements.content: The crystal structure of the Zn­(II) complex 1 was obtained in the monoclinic space group C2/c (a). Two of the four vinyl pyridyl moieties of the tetrasiloxane ligand are located in axial positions while the remaining two are at the equatorial positions. The tetrasiloxane backbone exhibits a chair conformation in which two of the four Si-bound methyl groups are located at the axial positions, and the remaining two are at the equatorial positions confirming the cis–trans–cis geometry for L1A in 1 (a). The coordination environment around the Zn­(II) ion can be described as distorted tetrahedral consisting of two terminal I– ions and two N-donor sites from two different tetrasiloxane ligands L1A. The four peripherally attached pyridyl groups of L1A are coordinated with four ZnI2 units, two on one side and two on the other side of the Si4O4 ring, leading to the formation of a one-dimensional ribbon-like structure. The individual 1D-chains are made-up of 28-membered macrocycles that are fused to each other on either side of the tetrasiloxane scaffold. The 1D-chains of the adjacent layers are aligned perpendicular to each other and linked via two distinct π–π interactions (3.610 and 3.917 Å) of the pyridyl groups (Figure S30, Supporting Information). The net effect of these π–π interactions is the formation of a supramolecular 3D-structure (b). TOPOS analysis gave the topology of a PtS net represented by the Schläfli symbol {42.84} (c). The 3D-packing structure of 1 reveals the presence of 1D-channels, and the void volume (excluding the disordered atoms) calculated by Mercury software is 1618.14 Å3 which amounts to 27% of the unit-cell volume. The gas adsorption analysis reveals a nonporous structure for 1. This is primarily attributed to the disordered nature of the tetrasiloxane and the vinylic C atoms (Figure S31, Supporting Information) which takes up a considerable amount of the void space present in 1.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 was solved in the triclinic space group P1̅ (). The siloxane ring displays a boat–chair conformation in which three of the four vinyl pyridyl moieties in 2 are located at equatorial positions while the fourth one is oriented in the axial position. The coordination environment around the Ag­(I) atom consists of two N-donor sites from two different L1B fragments (b). As a result, the molecule propagates into a one-dimensional polymeric structure with two distinct 32-membered Ag2L2-type macrocycles featuring alternately arranged wider- and narrower-ring segments. The wider 32-membered macrocycle is formed by the participation of one axial and one equatorial pyridyl segments from each of the two L1B fragments, whereas the remaining two equatorial pyridyl segments form the narrow-spaced macrocycles.

elements.content: The molecular structure of 3 was solved in monoclinic space groups P2/c (a). The tetrameric Si–O ring exhibits a distorted boat shape. The four ethyl pyridyl moieties take up the equatorial positions and are located alternately above and below the Si4O4 ring (c). The molecular core consists of a cubane-type Cu4I4 cluster in which each I– ion acts as a μ3-bridging ligand and the Cu­(I) ions are located in a tetrahedral coordination consisting of three I– contacts and one pyridyl N-donor coordination from L2C (b). In return, each ligand is bonded to four Cu4I4 clusters. Thus, both the ligands and the Cu4I4 clusters in 3 act as four connected nodes resulting in the formation of a two-dimensional metal–organic framework structure. TOPOS analysis gave a 4-connected uninodal sql/Shubnikov tetragonal plane net represented by the Schläfli symbol {44.62} for 3 (c). The repeating unit of 2D assembly in 3 consists of 34-membered Cu4L2 macrocycles.

elements.content: Compound 3a is a white powder at ambient temperature and light (a). Under UV excitation at 298 K, compound 3a shows an intense orange emission while cooling to 77 K shows an intense blue emission. Interestingly, the original emission color of 3a can be recovered again within 2 min upon gradually warming the sample to room temperature indicating a completely reversible thermochromic luminescence (b,c). To understand these phenomena, the excitation and emission spectra of 3a were recorded in the solid state, and the corresponding results are summarized in Table S4 (Supporting Information). At 298 K, the emission spectrum of 3a displays a single broad low energy (LE) emission band centered at 595 nm (λex = 375 nm). This is in agreement with the intense orange emission observed at room temperature, which can be attributed to the “cluster-centered” (3CC) emission consisting of a mixture of iodide to copper charge transfer (3XMCT) and metal d → s,p transitions. While at 77 K a new high energy (HE) band appears at 447 nm (λex = 375 nm), with the concomitant quenching of the 3CC-LE band (). This HE band is attributed to the iodide to ligand charge transfer and metal to ligand charge transfer (3XLCT/3MLCT) transitions. These observed triplet emission bands are characteristic of the copper iodide clusters and are closely comparable with those reported for traditional Cu4I4Py4 clusters. The decay measurements in 3a at 298 and 77 K gave the lifetime (τem) values of 1.1 and 162 μS, respectively (Figures S32–S34, Supporting Information). It is interesting to note that the retention of thermochromism due to the Cu4I4 core in the cluster MOF 3 is a rare instance since such thermochromic behavior is found to be absent in several infinite frameworks based on these clusters.

elements.content: In conclusion, this work demonstrates that Pd(0) catalyzed Heck-coupling reaction offers a facile route for obtaining pyridyl functionalized cyclosiloxanes, and a new family of tetrapyridyl substituted cyclotetrasiloxanes tethered by vinyl and ethyl spacers has been synthesized for the first time. Among the four known isomers of cyclotetrasiloxne scaffolds, three isomers, cis–trans–cis, cis–cis–trans, and all-trans, have been identified and isolated in quantitative yields for these 3-pyridyl functionalized tetramers. The stereochemistry of these ligands has been established with the help of 1H and 29Si NMR studies and from the crystal structures derived from the metalation of some of these ligands. The emission spectra and the luminescent decay profiles recorded on 3a reveal interesting thermochromic behavior for the 2D-MOF 3. Further studies are aimed at synthesizing new families of cyclotetrasiloxanes containing various metal-coordinating groups by utilizing this Heck-coupling approach. These ligands owing to their inherent conformational flexibility can be utilized to rationally design dynamically switchable functional framework materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, this work demonstrates that Pd(0) catalyzed Heck-coupling reaction offers a facile route for obtaining pyridyl functionalized cyclosiloxanes, and a new family of tetrapyridyl substituted cyclotetrasiloxanes tethered by vinyl and ethyl spacers has been synthesized for the first time. Among the four known isomers of cyclotetrasiloxne scaffolds, three isomers, cis-trans-cis, cis-cis-trans, and all-trans, have been identified and isolated in quantitative yields for these 3-pyridyl functionalized tetramers. The stereochemistry of these ligands has been established with the help of 1H and 29Si NMR studies and from the crystal structures derived from the metalation of some of these ligands. The emission spectra and the luminescent decay profiles recorded on 3a reveal interesting thermochromic behavior for the 2D-MOF 3. Further studies are aimed at synthesizing new families of cyclotetrasiloxanes containing various metal-coordinating groups by utilizing this Heck-coupling approach. These ligands owing to their inherent conformational flexibility can be utilized to rationally design dynamically switchable functional framework materials.

References

The 29Si NMR spectrum of commercial D4 Vi (95% pure) gives three major peaks at 32.42, 32.44, and 32.52 ppm in the ratio of 1:2:1 similar to those observed for the cis–cis–trans isomer L1B. A small hump around 32.42 may be attributed to some other (presumably cis–trans–cis) isomer. A single broad peak in both HPLC and GC analysis of D4 Vi further confirms this observation. Similarly, crystal structure of a Ni(0) complex reported in ref supports the existence of the cis–trans–cis isomer (Figures S35–S37, Supporting Information). However, the formation of three different isomers in cis–trans–cis, cis–cis–trans, and all-trans conformation for L1 shows a change in isomeric ratio during the reaction.

cln_elements.content:
L1: 3-Bromopyridine (7.18 g 44 mmol) and D4 Vi (3.92 g, 11 mmol) were kept under nitrogen in a 250 mL two neck round-bottom flask, equipped with magnetic stirrer and reflux condenser. The flask was purged with nitrogen for 15 min at room temperature, and then 15 mL of triethylamine and Pd­[P­(tBu3)2] (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was then stirred at 90 °C for 96 h. After cooling to room temperature, hexane (50 mL) was added, and the mixture was washed with water in a separating funnel. The organic layer was separated, filtered through Celite, and evaporated in vacuum, to yield 60% of the crude L1 as a yellowish-brown oily compound. The crude mixture was purified by column chromatography using tetrahydrofuran and chloroform (20:80) as eluent which gave three stereoisomers of L1, namely, the cis–trans–cis L1A, cis–cis–trans L1B, and all-trans L1C, in the respective 35, 60, and 5% compositions.

1: To a solution of L1A (10 mg, 0.015 mmol) in THF (1 mL), kept in a 10 cm long glass tube, was slowly layered a methanolic solution of ZnI2 (10 mg, 0.031 mmol). The layered solutions in the tube were kept at room temperature for 2 days to get colorless crystals of 1. FT-IR data in powdered sample (cm–1): 2956, 2924, 1605, 1581, 1482, 1432, 1262, 1193, 1135, 1062, 799, 700, 655. Anal. Calcd for C32H36Zn2­I4N4O4Si4: C, 29.76; H, 2.81; N, 4.34. Found: C, 29.65; H, 2.73; N, 4.40.

2: To a solution of L1B (12 mg, 0.018 mmol) in DCM (3 mL), kept in a 10 cm long glass tube, was added toluene (1 mL) followed by a careful layering of a solution of AgNO3 (6 mg, 0.036 mmol) in water (3 mL). The resulting slightly cloudy solution was kept in the dark for crystallization. Colorless crystals were obtained after 4 days. FT-IR data in powdered sample (cm–1): 2955, 2922, 1598, 1478, 1427, 1261, 1192, 1086, 1033, 853, 795, 702, 649. Anal. Calcd for C33H42­Ag2N6O12Si4: C, 38.01; H, 4.06; N, 8.06. Found: C, 38.35; H, 3.95; N, 8.20.

3: To a solution of L2C (10 mg, 0.015 mmol) in DCM (1 mL), kept in 10 cm long glass tube, was slowly layered CuI solution in acetonitrile (10 mg, 0.06 mmol). The layered solutions in the tube were kept at room temperature for 7 days to get colorless crystals of 3. FT-IR data in powdered sample (cm–1): 2955, 2922, 1598, 1478, 1427, 1261, 1192, 1086, 1033, 853, 795, 702, 649. Anal. Calcd for C32H44Cu4I4­N4O4Si4: C, 27.01; H, 3.12; N, 3.94. Found: C, 27.15; H, 3.20; N, 3.79.

cln_elements.content:
The crystal structure of the Zn­(II) complex 1 was obtained in the monoclinic space group C2/c (a). Two of the four vinyl pyridyl moieties of the tetrasiloxane ligand are located in axial positions while the remaining two are at the equatorial positions. The tetrasiloxane backbone exhibits a chair conformation in which two of the four Si-bound methyl groups are located at the axial positions, and the remaining two are at the equatorial positions confirming the cis–trans–cis geometry for L1A in 1 (a). The coordination environment around the Zn­(II) ion can be described as distorted tetrahedral consisting of two terminal I– ions and two N-donor sites from two different tetrasiloxane ligands L1A. The four peripherally attached pyridyl groups of L1A are coordinated with four ZnI2 units, two on one side and two on the other side of the Si4O4 ring, leading to the formation of a one-dimensional ribbon-like structure. The individual 1D-chains are made-up of 28-membered macrocycles that are fused to each other on either side of the tetrasiloxane scaffold. The 1D-chains of the adjacent layers are aligned perpendicular to each other and linked via two distinct π–π interactions (3.610 and 3.917 Å) of the pyridyl groups (Figure S30, Supporting Information). The net effect of these π–π interactions is the formation of a supramolecular 3D-structure (b). TOPOS analysis gave the topology of a PtS net represented by the Schläfli symbol {42.84} (c). The 3D-packing structure of 1 reveals the presence of 1D-channels, and the void volume (excluding the disordered atoms) calculated by Mercury software is 1618.14 Å3 which amounts to 27% of the unit-cell volume. The gas adsorption analysis reveals a nonporous structure for 1. This is primarily attributed to the disordered nature of the tetrasiloxane and the vinylic C atoms (Figure S31, Supporting Information) which takes up a considerable amount of the void space present in 1.

Photophysical Properties

Compound 3a is a white powder at ambient temperature and light (a). Under UV excitation at 298 K, compound 3a shows an intense orange emission while cooling to 77 K shows an intense blue emission. Interestingly, the original emission color of 3a can be recovered again within 2 min upon gradually warming the sample to room temperature indicating a completely reversible thermochromic luminescence (b,c). To understand these phenomena, the excitation and emission spectra of 3a were recorded in the solid state, and the corresponding results are summarized in Table S4 (Supporting Information). At 298 K, the emission spectrum of 3a displays a single broad low energy (LE) emission band centered at 595 nm (λex = 375 nm). This is in agreement with the intense orange emission observed at room temperature, which can be attributed to the “cluster-centered” (3CC) emission consisting of a mixture of iodide to copper charge transfer (3XMCT) and metal d → s,p transitions. While at 77 K a new high energy (HE) band appears at 447 nm (λex = 375 nm), with the concomitant quenching of the 3CC-LE band (). This HE band is attributed to the iodide to ligand charge transfer and metal to ligand charge transfer (3XLCT/3MLCT) transitions. These observed triplet emission bands are characteristic of the copper iodide clusters and are closely comparable with those reported for traditional Cu4I4Py4 clusters. The decay measurements in 3a at 298 and 77 K gave the lifetime (τem) values of 1.1 and 162 μS, respectively (Figures S32–S34, Supporting Information). It is interesting to note that the retention of thermochromism due to the Cu4I4 core in the cluster MOF 3 is a rare instance since such thermochromic behavior is found to be absent in several infinite frameworks based on these clusters.
